Andrea relates that every market day she works selling clothes.  She has well-established sales spots in all the sites.  “I do very well when I sell in the markets.  My normal routine is to go when the women receive their support stipends.  I enjoy selling this type of clothing because it sells quite easily.”  She also states that she’d like to have more variety to attract and please more customers.  She will use the loan she’ll get to buy a wider variety of clothes which will help her gradually expand her business.  Andrea wants to enlarge the business because she wants her children to finish their schooling and have better quality of life.

Juana will invest in cleaning supplies, Jesús will invest in underwear and Fidencio will invest in toys and novelty items.  These are people who have been clients of the institution for several cycles already so they are very grateful and happy for the help Kiva and VisionFund México provide because they relate that their businesses have grown favorably and even though sales aren’t what they used to be they are still able to have better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy infant wear.

location.town: Santa Cruz Mextepec, San Felipe del Progreso

loans.name: Colibri Ruiseñor Group

texts.es: El grupo “Colibrí Ruiseñor” es la primera vez que está trabajando con la institución esta conformado por seis integrantes todas son mujeres muy trabajadoras y responsables pero sobretodo muy alegres, todas se conocen entre ellas, el nombre del grupo lo eligieron porque les gusto pero solo habían optado por el nombre de Colibrí sin embargo la coordinadora las ayudo con el nombre de Ruiseñor. Doña Bonifacia es la representante del grupo tiene 37 años de edad esta casada desde hace 17 años con el señor Alfonso quien trabaja como obrero juntos han formado una familia con tres niños los cuales se encuentran estudiando, Doña Bonifacia se dedica a la crianza y engorda de pavos desde hace 17 años cuenta Doña Bonifacia comento: “Inicie mi actividad porque creo que es bueno siempre tener un dinerito extra muy independiente del sueldo de mi esposo para poder ayudar con los gastos del hojar y educción de mis hijos. Doña Bonifacia compra sus guajolotes desde que están chicos porque asi le salen mas baratos los crece y engorada por un tiempo para venderlos a un precio más alto normalmente se los piden sus mismas vecinas de la comunidad cuando hay alguna fiesta, Esta Vez está solicitando el crédito para poder comprar más pavos si le llega a sobrar también comprara alimento, “Es una actividad que aprendí de mi mama desde que yo era una niña ahora los crio para poder vender cuando estoy en una situación económica difícil” Sin embargo ya con mucha experiencia Doña Bonifacia aun enfrenta la enfermedad de sus animalitos por lo que  esto presenta una pérdida de inversión de ganancia, cuenta que normalmente cuando sucede esto ella se dé obligada a solventar un gasto extra para medicamentos y vitaminas para poder recuperar sus pavos y no se mueran. La meta de Doña Bonifacia es que algún día sus hijos tengan una mejor calidad de vida que puedan cumplir sus sueños como ejercer una carrera “Si en mis manos esta de ayudarlos lo haremos junto con mi esposo” Doña Bonifacia y las integrantes del grupo está muy contentas y agradecidas con el crédito otorgado ya que podrán mejorar sus actividades ellas se comprometen a no quedar mal en sus pagos trabajar mucho para seguir mejorando Doña Carmen invertirá en sus bordados, Diana, Elia, Ángeles y Ofelia compraran borregos para cría y engorada de borregos.
texts.en:
The communal bank “Colibrí Ruiseñor” (Hummingbird Nightingale) is working with the institution for the first time and comprises six hardworking, responsible, and very happy women, who all know each other. The members chose the group name "Hummingbird" because they liked it; however, the coordinator helped them choose "Nightingale." Bonifacia, 37, is the group's representative. She has been married to Alfonso, a laborer, for 17 years, and they have three school-age children. 

Bonifacia has been raising turkeys for 17 years. She says, "I started this activity because I thought that having extra money besides my husband's income and being able to help with the household expenses and my children's education was always a good thing." Bonifacia buys very young turkeys because they are cheap. She raises and fattens them to sell at a higher price, usually to her neighbors when there is a holiday.

She has applied for this loan to buy more turkeys, and if there is money left, to buy feed. "I learned this trade as a girl from my mother, who raised turkeys to sell when times were hard." Though she has a lot of experience, Bonifacia's turkeys get sick at times, which means she could lose her investment. When sickness occurs, she has to spend more on medication and vitamins so that her animals recover and don't die.

Bonifacia's goal is to see her children have a better life and achieve their dreams of having a career. “If it is possible, my husband and I will help them." Bonifacia and the group members are happy and grateful for the loan, which will improve their businesses. They promise to make their payments and keep working to improve. Carmen will invest in her needlework. Diana, Elia, Ángeles, and Ofelia will buy sheep to raise and fatten.

loans.use: to buy turkeys.

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Akossiwa vit avec son conjoint magasinier et leur enfant de 04 ans à Lomé. Âgée de 35ans, elle revend seule des chaussures dans un marché de la ville de Lomé depuis 2003. Afin de mieux servir ses clients, elle sollicite un second crédit à WAGES pour acheter des chaussures. Elle espère avec les profits tirés de la vente renforcer son commerce et assurer les besoins primaires de la famille.
texts.en: Akossiwa lives with her storekeeper spouse and their 4 year old child in Lomé. Thirty-five years old, she has been reselling shoes alone in a market in the city of Lomé since 2003. In order to better serve her customers, she is requesting a second loan from WAGES to buy shoes. With the profits from the sales she hopes to strengthen her business and ensure the primary needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy shoes.

loans.name: Riaz

texts.en:
Ms Riaz is a married woman and a mother of five children. She is trying hard to fulfill their demands, including food, health care, clothing, and education.   She and her husband are doing work in agriculture, which they have done for nine years. The man shown in the photo is Riaz’s husband. They grow different vegetables and sell them in the local market.  Her son also assists her in growing the various crops, by watering soil for good quality production.

She has gradually improved her business, with the support of Kashf Foundation. In order to purchase different kinds of seeds, and packs of insecticides and pesticides, Riaz applied for a loan of Rs. 15,000. This would help her to grow more crops, which ultimately helps in generating more cash.

loans.use: to purchase different kinds of seeds, and packs of insecticides and pesticides.

loans.name: Bonita Luna Group

texts.es: El Grupo “Bonita Luna” está integrado por personas muy trabajadoras y muy alegres son siete integrantes uno de ellos es hombre y el resto son mujeres. Los integrantes son personas que tienen una actividad productiva es por eso que están solicitando crédito a la institución para poder invertirle a sus actividades como Abel invertirá en la cría y engorda de borregos, Rosario en  tienda de abarrotes, Sara invertirá en su zapatería, Lluvia en su jacieria, candelaria y Daniela invertirán en sus pollos. Doña Juanita como así le dicen de cariño también es integrante del grupo tiene 47 años de edad vive en unión libre con el señor Francisco quien trabaja en el campo por el momento solo ya tienen dos hijos que dependen de ellos y que se encuentran estudiando, Doña Juanita tiene una tienda de abarrotes desde hace siete años platica que inicio vendiendo refrescos y huevo que eran los productos que más se vendían con mucha facilidad porque son productos que más se consumen empezó a vender más productos porque las personas de la misma comunidad le preguntaban porque no vendía otros productos ya que para los vecinos de la comunidad eran indispensables en su hogar. Doña Juanita cuenta que poco a poco ha ido creciendo por ejemplo antes no tenía un lugar bien establecido ahora ya lo tiene solo que por el momento le hace falta un buen mostrador porque tiene una mesa donde pone algunas cosas también quiere le hace falta comprar un refrigerador para iniciar a vender lácteos y carnes frías lo que ayudaría mucho para poder crecer su tienda de abarrotes. Doña Juanita comento “Me gustaría que mi negocio creciera para poder ayudar a mis hijos para que ellos puedan terminar una carrera profesional y tengan un mejor futuro y no pasen por las mis dificultades que nosotros como padres estamos viviendo”.
texts.en:
The “Bonita Luna” (Pretty Moon) group is composed of very hardworking, very cheerful people.  There are seven members; one of them is a man and the rest are women.  The members are people who have productive activities which is why they are requesting credit from the institution to be able to invest in their activities.  For example, Abel will invest in raising and fattening up sheep, Rosario in a grocery store, Sara in her shoe shop, Lluvia in cleaning supplies, Candelaria and Daniela in chickens.

Juanita, as she’s affectionately called, is also a group member.   She’s 47-years-old and lives in a free union with Francisco who for the moment works in the fields; they have two children who depend on them and are attending school.  Juanita has had a grocery store for seven years and she relates that she stared out selling soft-drinks and eggs which were the products that sold the most and more easily because they are products that are consumed the most but later started to sell other things because the people in the community themselves would ask her why she didn’t sell other things that were indispensable for the homes of the members of the community.  

Juanita relates that she’s gradually been growing.  For example, she used to not have well-established site and now she does although at present she still needs a good display case because she places some things on a table; she also needs to buy a refrigerator to start selling dairy products and cold cuts that would be very conducive to her business’ growth.

Juanita said: “I would like my business to grow so that I can help my children finish professional careers so they can have better futures and not have to go through the difficulties we as parents are going through.”

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for her store.

location.town: Los Lobos Segunda Seccion, San Jose del Rincon

loans.name: Concepcion Primitiva

texts.es: La Sra. Concepción, tiene 56 años, ella se dedica a la venta de frutas de temporada, ella tiene su puesto desde hace ya bastante tiempo en uno d elos mercados mas concurridos de la zona Sud de la ciudad de La Paz,  en esta  ocasión solicita el crédito para la compra de frutas según la temporada, la Sra. Concepción es una cliente responsable quien trabaja con nosotros desde hace tiempo, La Sra. Concepción enfrenta retos en su negocio que son salir de la pobreza y  va a utilizar los beneficios para mejorar su calidad de vida y la  de su familia su  sueño para su negocio es ser una de las mejores comerciantes y crecer en su negocio para así generar más ingresos ya que este es la única  actividad que le permite mantenerse.
texts.en: Concepción, 56, works selling seasonal fruits. She has had her stand for some time in one of the busiest markets in the south of La Paz. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits. Concepción is a responsible client who has worked with us for awhile. She confronts challenges in her business such as getting out of poverty. She will use the profits to improve her and her family's quality of life. Her dream is to be one of the best businesswomen and grow in her business. That way, she will earn more income, since this is the only activity she has to support herself.

loans.use: to buy seasonal fruits

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to build a room.

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Madame Aminata est née en 1966 à Niena où elle vit dans une famille traditionnelle avec son époux (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle mène des activités d’achat et de vente de céréales depuis une dizaine d’année. Son expérience dans ce domaine, lui a valu une bonne réputation et reçoit des commandes de divers clients. Ainsi pour avoir les ressources nécessaires afin de satisfaire ses clients, elle décida de collaborer avec l’Institution de Micro Finance Soro Yiriwaso, avec qui elle a déjà eu  4 prêts tous remboursés.  
Ce nouveau prêt lui permettra d’acheter 2 tonnes et demi de maïs. Elle s’approvisionne à Niena auprès des producteurs et dans les villages environnants. Les ventes sont faites au niveau du village de Niena. Sa clientèle est composée pour la plus part d’hommes. 
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 45.000 FCFA par mois. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de faire face aux échéances de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
Elle compte devenir un grossiste de bonne renommée.
texts.en:
Madam Aminata was born in 1966 in Niena where she lives in a traditional family with her spouse (third administrative region of the republic of Mali).

She has been managing businesses buying and selling cereals for about 10 years. Her experience in this domain has brought her a good reputation and she receives orders from a variety of customers. Thus to have the resources necessary to satisfy her customers, she decided to collaborate with the Microfinance Institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she has already had 4 loans all repaid.

This new loan will allow her to buy 2 tons and a half of corn. She gets her supplies in Niena from the producers and in the surrounding villages. Her sales are made in the village of Niena. Her clientele consists mostly of men.

With this loan, she envisions making an average monthly profit of 45,000 FCFA per month. This profit will allow her to meet the financial obligations of her loan and to invest the rest in her business. 

She plans to become a wholesaler with a good reputation.

loans.use: to buy cereals.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy merchandise.

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Monsieur Moussa  est né vers 1956 et vit avec ses deux femmes et ses enfants à Niena. Un des commune de la troisième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Il mène des activités d’achat et de vente de pneus et chambre à air d’occasion depuis plus de 20 ans. Son expérience dans ce domaine, lui a valu une bonne réputation et reçoit des commandes de divers clients. Ainsi pour avoir les ressources nécessaires afin de satisfaire ces clients, il décida de collaborer avec l’Institution de Micro Finance Soro Yiriwaso, il ya 4 ans,  tous les prêts précédant ont été correctement remboursés.  
Ce prêt lui permettra d’acheter 100 pneus et quelques chambre à air. Il  s’approvisionne au marché de Sikasso ainsi qu’à Bamako. Les ventes sont faites à Niena comme au niveau des foires hebdomadaires fréquentées. Sa clientèle est composée principalement d’hommes. 
Avec ce prêt, Mr Moussa envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 75 000  FCFA par mois. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer les échéances de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mister Moussa was born around 1956 and lives with his two wives and his children in Niena, one of the communes of the third administrative region of the republic of Mali.

He has been managing businesses buying and selling used tires and inner tubes for more than 20 years. His experience in this domain has brought him a good reputation and he gets orders from a variety of customers. Thus to have the resources necessary to satisfy his customers, he decided to collaborate with the Micro-Finance Institution Soro Yiriwaso 4 years ago. All previous loans have been correctly repaid.

This loan will allow him to buy 100 tires and several inner tubes. He gets his supplies at the market of Sikasso as well as in Bamako. His sales are made in Niena for example at the busy weekly fairs. His clientele consists primarily of men.

With his loan, Mister Moussa envisions making an average monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA per month. This profit will allow him to meet the financial obligations of his loan and to invest the rest in his business.

loans.use: to buy tires and inner tubes.

loans.name: Hina

texts.en: Hina is a married woman and the mother of three children. She has been running a business purchasing and selling animals the past two years. She buys animals (baby goats and baby cows) at low prices, raises them and then sells them in the market at higher prices. She is in charge of providing her family with bread and butter. In order to purchase two more goats, she requested a loan of PKR 25,000 from Kashf Foundation. She hopes to grow her business, and she dreams of providing a better standard of living to her children through all her hard work in her business.

loans.use: to purchase two more goats.

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en:
Naseem is a 36-year-old, married woman. She is running a business of ‘Pakora’ making and sales. Pakora is a dish consisting of pieces of vegetable and chicken, dipped in a gram flour or 'besan.' She has been doing this business with the support of her husband for the past many years. The man shown in the photo is Naseem’s husband. They earn enough through this business to contribute to the family's income. 

In order to inflate their sales, Naseem needs to purchase a stock of gram flour, along with packs of oil, salt, and spices. For this, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of PKR 40,000. She is in her sixth loan cycle, with good repayment history. She wishes to spend part of the revenue on the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to purchase for her business a stock of gram flour, along with packs of oil, salt, and spices.

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
Ellen lives in Sinkor, in Montserrado County, the capital city of Liberia. It is well-known as the commercial city of Liberia. She is 30 year old, married, with three children between the ages of 3 and 10. 

Since 1997, she has been selling dried fish from a table in the local market. She started this business with the help of her husband and learned this way of selling from him. She likes her business because it gives her more profits and makes her popular.

She is requesting a loan to purchase dried fish for her business. She wants to get more money to build her house since she has a piece of land.

loans.use: to purchase dried fish for her business.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe BENKADI sont essentiellement des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 29 ans, et ont en moyenne  4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Dougoukolobougou, un village situé à environ 20 km de Niena soit 95 km de la ville de Sikasso. 
Elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme     MAMOU fait le commerce de condiment dans ce groupe de femmes. Elle se tient debout à l’extrême droite.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt diverses sortes de  condiments (concentrées de tomates, sel, piments, cube maggi et beurre de karité) qu’elle revend en détail sur place et au marché de  Dougoukolobougou . 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.000 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The six members of the group Benkadi are essentially married women who are on average 29 years old, and have on average 4 children.

Most of them live in polygamous families in Dougoukolobougou, a village located approximately 20km from Niena and 95km from the town of Sikasso.

They are on their second loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso due to the concern of satisfying the needs of their clientele.

Madam Mamou sells condiments in this group of women. She is standing on the far right.

With her loan she plans to buy a variety of condiments (tomato concentrate, salt, pepper, maggi cubes and shea butter) which she resells retail on the spot and at the market of Dougoukolobougou.

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 17,000 FCFA of which part is used to pay the loan and its interest and the other for her savings.

loans.use: to buy condiments.

loans.name: Badegna Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  membres du groupe BADEGNA sont essentiellement de femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, et ont en moyenne  5 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans Des  familles monogamiques à  Médine un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur 13ème  prêt  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme MOUSSOKORO fait le commerce de savons  dans ce groupe de femmes. Elle se tient en première position à gauche.
Elle compte acheter 12 cartons de  savons qu’elle revendra en détail sur place et au marché de Médine. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17 500 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The four members of the group Badegna are essentially married women who are on average 40 years old and have on average 5 children.

Most of them live in polygamous families in Médine, one of the popular neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso in the third administrative region of Mali.

They are on their 13th loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso due to the concern of satisfying the needs of their clientele.

Madam Moussokoro sells soaps in this group of women. She is in the first position on the left.

She plans to buy 12 cartons of soaps which she will resell retail on the spot and at the market of Médine.

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 17,500 FCFA of which part is used to pay the loan and its interest and the other for her savings.

loans.use: to buy soaps.

loans.name: Jiguiseme Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe JIGUISEME sont essentiellement de femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, et ont en moyenne  4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogamiques à  Médine, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur 11ème  prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme     MAIMOUNA  fait le commerce de tissus dans  ce groupe de femmes. Elle se tient en quatrième position de la gauche vers la droite.
Elle compte acheter deux rouleaux de tissus qu’elle revendra en détail sur place et au marché de Médine. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.500FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The six members of the group Jiguiseme are essentially married women who are on average 40 years old, and have on average 4 children.

Most of them live in monogamous families in  Médine, one of the popular neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso in the third administrative region of Mali.

They are on their 11th loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso due to the concern of satisfying the needs of their clientele.

Madam Maimouna sells fabric in this group of women. She is in the fourth position from left to right.

She plans to buy two rolls of fabric which she will resell retail on the spot and at the market in Médine.

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 17,500 FCFA of which part is used to pay the loan and its interest and the other for her savings.

Her ambition is to increase her turnover to better satisfy her clientele.

loans.use: to buy fabric.

loans.name: Leandro

texts.es:
Don Leandro un humilde señor de 36 años de edad, originario de la Comarcas el Nancintal, en las afueras de Teustepe, casado, padre de 4 hijos de 6, 10, 13 y 15 años de edad, todos están estudiando,  de oficio agricultor, se dedica a una de las actividades mas comunes de la Ciudad de Teustepe como es  la siembra de maíz, frijoles y trigo, del que es propietario hace mas de 12 años, debido a sus condiciones de pobreza no logro estudiar. 
Inicio su actividad agrícola, ayudándoles a sus padres en las tierras, luego decide independizarse, empieza a sembrar por si solo con dinero propio, Leandro no solo se encarga de la siembra, sino que también ordeña sus vaquitas, en sus trabajos de siembra paga mozos. Sus productos lo comercializan en Managua. Sus expectativas es aumentar la producción de su siembra y sus animales.
Leandro requiere de este crédito para pagar mano de obra, comprar insumos, abonos y fertilizantes, que le hacen falta para la siembra del frijol y maíz de este año. Este crédito será de ayuda ya que podrá darle mejor preparación a las tierras y obtendrá mayor rendimiento de la cosecha, sus planes futuros  es cancelar el crédito con las ganancias que le genere la cosecha y lo que le quede hacerle mejoras a su vivienda, sus metas próximas es mantener su negocio activo, generar mejores ingresos para poder salir adelante con su familia.
texts.en:
Don Leandro is a humble man of 36. He is a native of the Nacintal district on the outskirts of Teustepe. He is married and is the father of four children, ages 6, 10, 13, and 15. All of them are in school. His work is farming. He works in one of the most common activities in the city of Teustepe, which is planting corn, beans, and wheat. He has been in this business for more than 12 years. Due to his impoverished condition, he was not able to go to school. He began his agricultural activity by helping his parents on the land. Then he decided to become independent. He began to plant for himself with his own money. Leandro not only takes charge of planting, but he also milks his cows. In his planting work he pays helpers. He sells his products in Managua. His expectations are to increase the production of his plantings and his animals.

Leandro needs this loan to pay for labor and buy supplies, compost, and fertilizer, which he needs to plant beans and corn this year. This loan will be of help to him because he will be able to better prepare the fields and obtain a better yield from the harvest. His future plans are to pay off the loan with the earnings that the harvest will generate and with what remains make improvements in his house. His next goals are to keep his business active and generate more income to be able to advance with his family.

loans.use: to pay for labor and buy supplies, compost, and fertilizer

loans.name: Fareeda

texts.en:
Ms Fareeda is a 47-year-old, married woman and a mother of six children. She is running a business of book-selling, with the support of her husband. The man shown in the photo is Fareeda’s husband. They have gained four years of experience in this field. They sell religious books to the people of their community, door-to-door, and they earn enough to lead a decent a life.

In order to buy a greater variety of books, considering the demands of the customers, Fareeda requested a loan of Rs. 20,000 from Kashf Foundation. She expects a boost in her earnings and dreams of expanding her business in the near future.

loans.use: to buy a greater variety of books, considering the demands of the customers.

loans.name: Afshan

texts.en:
Ms Afshan is a 32-year-old, married woman. She is successfully running a small general store, with her husband, at the corner of her house. Her husband also assists her by purchasing their stock of goods from the market, at wholesale rates. She is a mother of three children and is motivated to provide her family with good-quality food, clothing and healthcare.  She also does teaching as her part-time job; in this way, she is able to meet the needs of the family members efficiently.

She wants to grow her business, so she requested a loan of PKR 25,000. She will use it to buy packs of salt, biscuits and sugar, to meet the increasing demand at her store. She is expecting a boost in her earnings and dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy packs of salt, biscuits and sugar, to meet the increasing demand at her store.

loans.name: Darling Elicia

texts.es: Darling Elicia de 29 años,  casada, madre de tres hijos en edades escolares, vive en el departamento de Chinandega ubicado en el occidente del país, se dedica a la venta de artesanías, muebles de madera y platería. Las artesanías son productos elaborados manualmente, hechos de barro, arcilla, madera y metales, son parte de la cultura Nicaragüense y parte de las raíces de Darling. Inició hace diez años con ahorros propios que logro acumular con muchos años de esfuerzo, para ayudar a su esposo  a solventar los gastos de su hogar y construir un mejor futuro para sus hijos. Además, vende comida tres o cuatro veces a la semana dentro de las mismas instalaciones de su negocio de artesanías. Darling solicita este crédito para fortalecer su capital de trabajo y comprar productos típicos de Nicaragua como: hamacas, juguetes de madera, sillones de madera, mecedoras tejidas, entre otras.  Dentro de sus sueños esta formar a sus hijos profesionalmente.  Darling agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas Kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Darling Elicia is 29, married, and the mother of three school aged children. She lives in the Chinandega department located in the west of the country. She sells artisan crafts, wooden furniture, and silver. The artisan crafts are handmade products, made from different kinds of clay, wood, and metals. They are part of the Nicaraguan culture and part of Darling’s roots. She started her business ten years ago with her own savings that she managed to save up with a lot of effort over many years. She wanted to help her husband pay for the household expenses and provide a better future for her children. In addition, she sells food three or four times a week in the same facilities as her artisan shop. 

Darling is requesting the loan to bolster her working capital and purchase traditional Nicaraguan products such as hammocks, wooden toys, wooden chairs, and rocking chairs with woven seats. 

One of her dreams is to develop her children professionally. Darling is thankful for the help of the Kiva investors who support people with scarce resources in poor countries such as Nicaragua and allow them to have a means of dignified work.

loans.use: purchase hammocks, wooden toys, wooden chairs, rocking chairs, and more

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
Sonia, 41 años de edad, originario de la Comarca la Ceiba, Teustepe, casada, madre de 5 hijos,  de oficio comerciante, se dedica al negocio de pulpería y a la venta de comida, de la que es propietaria hace más de 1 año. 
Inicio su pequeño negocio capital propio, dinero que tenia ahorrado, ya que  con mucho esfuerzo y arduo trabajo, comenzó  vendiendo piedras canteras de formas ambulante con su marido,  con las ganancias que le genero este negocio pudo poner la pulpería y la venta de comida, se siente muy bien porque este negocio le genera ganancias a diario, recibe el apoyo de sus hijos, sus productos lo comercializa en la misma comunidad en donde vive, unas de sus expectativas es ampliar su negocio.
Sonia está solicitando el préstamo para comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, jabón, gaseosa, pollo, etc. Con el propósito de surtir su inventario de productos comestibles y mejorar las  ventas para obtener ganancias  que le permita seguir invirtiendo en si negocio para crecer.
texts.en:
Sonia, who is 41, is a native of the district of Ceiba, in Teustepe. She is married and is the mother of five children. She is a businesswoman. She works in the grocery and food-selling business, where she has been the proprietor of a business for more than one year.

She began her little business with her own capital, money that she had saved, since with much effort and hard work, she and her husband started out selling and delivering quarry stone for construction. With the earnings that this business generated for her, she was able to set up the grocery store and the sale of food. She feels very good because this business generates daily earnings for her. She receives help from her children. She sells her products in the same community where she lives. One of her expectations is to expand her business.

Sonia is applying for the loan to buy rice, sugar, oil, soap, soft drinks, chicken, etc., with the goal of stocking her inventory of food products and improving her sales to obtain earnings that will allow her to continue investing in her business in order to grow.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, oil, soap, soft drinks, chicken, etc. for her store

loans.name: Miski Ñawi Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “MISKI ÑAWI”  iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Panamericana, está compuesta por seis integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Carmen Rosa es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de comida (pensión), taller de costura, tejido a mano, tejido de chalecos y mantas, venta de fruta.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Carmen Rosa es integrante, ella indica que es la primera vez que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de un familiar que le invitó a participar en un grupo ya que ella es una socia de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de comida (pensión); da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió a recomendación de su madre y de un anterior negocio que tenía, actualmente realiza esta actividad en las instalaciones de su hogar.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de máquina de fritado de pollo) que adquirirá de las ferias de la ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para sostener su economía.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el apoyo en salud.
texts.en:
The MISKI ÑAWI communal bank will begin its first cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the Panamericana Center.  The bank is made up of six members and directed by a board of directors where Carmen Rosa serves as the president.  The members have various businesses including food sales, sewing, knitting by hand, vest and shirt making, and fruit sales.
 
This loan will benefit the small businesses, including Carmen Rosa’s.  This is the first time she has been a part of Pro Mujer and she joined after having been invited by a relative who is also a member.  She has a food selling business and started this business on her mother’s recommendation and from a previous business.  She currently works from home.

She is asking for this loan in order to increase her working capital (to buy a chicken fryer).  She will buy it in the La Paz fairs and then make and sell in her selling area.  This will allow her to generate an income with which to support her financial needs.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she says that she likes the health care support.

loans.use: to buy a chicken fryer.

loans.name: Nuestra Fe Esta En Dios Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “NUESTRA FE ESTA EN DIOS”  iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Senkata, está compuesta por seis integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Elena es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: tienda de barrio, venta de dulces, venta de chamarras, venta de comida.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Elena es integrante, ella indica que es la primera vez que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de su amiga que es socia de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de tienda de barrio; da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió por iniciativa propia, en la actualidad la tiene cerrada, ya que no tenía mucha mercadería.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de refrescos, enlatados, abarrotes) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas de la ciudad de La Paz y lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta le gusta las capacitaciones en salud y crédito.
texts.en:
Nuestra Fe Está en Dios Communal Bank will begin its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Senkata regional office.  It's made up of six members governed by a board of directors of which Elena is the president.  The various businesses of the communal bank members include a neighborhood store, candy sales, jacket sales, and food sales.
 
This loan will benefit small business entrepreneurs such as Elena.  She says it's the first time she has been a member of Pro Mujer, having joined on the invitation of her friend who's a member of the institution.

Currently she has a neighborhood store business.  She says she undertook this business on her own initiative.  Currently it's closed because she didn't have a lot of merchandise.

The loan she's getting now is to increase her capital by buying soft drinks, canned goods, and groceries, which she'll get from wholesale vendors in the city of La Paz and then sell in her sales stall.  This type of work allows her to generate resources to support her household as much as possible, because she's married and has two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer she says the health and loan training.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, canned goods, and groceries

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 52 years old, married, and has 13 children. Three are still in elementary education. She buys and sells fish on a house-to-house basis. 

She is now asking for a loan of PHP 7,000 to buy more fish (e.g., catfish, milkfish) to sell. She hopes to acquire more profits for her business to sustain her children's education needs. She hopes to keep improving her sales, to earn more funds, to save for family's future expenses.

loans.use: to buy more fish (e.g., catfish, milkfish) to sell.

loans.name: Tamaz

texts.en:
Tamaz is 24 years old. He lives in a small village of Khobi District, with his parents. Tamaz requested a loan from local financial institutions several times, for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is their the agricultural activities. In particular, they have a vineyard and a plot of agricultural land, where nut trees are grown. They sell the harvested products locally. It is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Recently, Tamaz requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. His loan request was approved, in the frame of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The Start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and restart-up credits, with soft conditions, to rural poor people, who do not have access to other credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income.

With the received credit, Tamaz will start a car wash. He will purchase the essential car-washing equipment and vacuum cleaners for starting the business. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the income and living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to buy the necessary equipment for starting up a new car wash business

loans.name: Tete

texts.en:
Tete lives in Sinkor in Montserrado County the capital city county of Liberia, which is well known as the commercial heart of Liberia. She is 50 years old and is married with five children, only one of whom is at school and still living at home. 

Since 1990 she has been selling fresh fish in the local market. She started this business with help from her mother and learned this way of selling from her. She likes her business because it gives her profits and makes her popular.

She is requesting a loan to buy more fresh fish for her business. She wants to get more money to build her house and buy a car.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fish for her business.

loans.name: Bertha Claudia

texts.es: Berta Claudia una  mujer de 45 años, soltera, y madre de un hijo, originaria del departamento de Chinandega ubicado en el occidente de Nicaragua. Se dedica a la venta de comida por las noches en el país popularmente llamadas “FRITANGAS” consideradas la comida rápida del país como: enchiladas, tacos, tajadas y asados, además comida rápida poco tradicional como: hot dogs, hamburguesas, sopas instantáneas también por las mañanas se dedica a realizar tratamientos de belleza a domicilio es una mujer trabajadora y sabe que su tiempo es muy valioso y lo debe de invertir en sus negocios, inicio el negocio hace 5 años como herencia de su mamá que era una de las mejores cocineras de la localidad, ella trabaja arduamente porque en un futuro ella desea remodelar su casa. Berta solicita este crédito para comprar: granos básicos, aceite, estufa para hacer su rica comida de manera más rápida ya que solo tiene un pequeño cocinero rustico, ella esta muy agradecidas con los inversionistas kivas porque le han brindado la oportunidad de poder salir adelante
texts.en: Berta Claudia, 45, is single and has one child. She is originally from Chinadega Department in western Nicaragua. At night, she sells food that is popularly called "fritangas", considered to be the country's fast food, like enchiladas, tacos, tajadas, and asados, as well as less traditional fast food like hot dogs, hamburgers, and instant soups. In the mornings, she works giving people beauty treatments in their homes. She is a very hard-working woman and she knows that her time is very valuable and she needs to invest it in her businesses. She started the business five years ago. It was an inheritance from her mother, who was one of the best cooks in the area. She works hard because she wants to remodel her home in the future. She is asking for this loan to buy basic grains, oil, and a cooker to make her delicious food faster. Currently she only has a small rustic stove. She is very grateful to Kiva lenders because they have given her this opportunity to move forward.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, oil, and a cooker to make her delicious food faster

loans.name: San Roque Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “SAN ROQUE”  iniciará el cuarto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Panamericana, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Emma es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de productos de limpieza, venta de helado, tejido de chompas, tienda de ferretería, venta de polainas y chalinas, venta de cosméticos, venta de chompas, venta de comida 

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Emma es integrante, ella indica que hace año y medio que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de un promotor de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de tejido y venta chompas de mujer; da a conocer que este negocio lo inicio por recomendación de su hermana que le enseño las cualidades del negocio.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de lana) que adquirirá de las ferias de la ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella es soltera y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el apoyo en salud.
texts.en:
San Roque Communal Bank will start its fourth loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Panamericana regional office.  It's made up of eight members and governed by a board of directors of which Emma is the president.  The various businesses of the communal bank members include cleaning product sales, ice cream sales, knitting sweaters, hardware store, leggings and shawl sales, cosmetics sales, sweater sales, and food sales.

This loan will benefit small business entrepreneurs such as Emma.  She says she has been a member of Pro Mujer for a year and a half, having been invited to join by a loan officer from the institution who visited her at home.

Currently she has a business knitting and selling women's sweaters.  She says she started this business on the recommendation of her sister, who taught her the characteristics of the business.

The loan she's getting now is to increase her capital by buying wool, which she'll acquire from the markets in the city of La Paz and, after production, sell in her sales stall.  This type of work allows her to generate resources to support her household as much as possible, because she's single and has two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer she says the health support.

loans.use: to buy wool

loans.name: Garmai

texts.en:
Garmai lives in Sinkor, in Montserrado County which is the county of the capital city of Liberia, and well known as the commercial city of Liberia. She is 45 years old, and married with four children between the ages of 13 and 31; only one is in school and lives at home.

For the past twenty years she has been running a table in the local market where she sells rice, pepper, bitter ball, vita, etc. She started this business with the help of her mother and learned this way of selling from her. She likes her business because it gives her good profits and makes her popular. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase more pepper, bitter ball, rice, vita, etc for her business. She wants to get more money to expand her business to a shop.

loans.use: to purchase more pepper, bitter ball, rice and vita for her business.

loans.name: Temur

texts.en:
Temur is 23 years old and is from the Senaki District. He has a large family: a wife, an infant son, a mother, a cousin, a step-daughter and a grandmother, who is provided with a retirement pension. Temur requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of his low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

Temur has a commercial space, which is rented and they get 650 Laris (GEL) per month. It is hardly enough for food for such a large family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Temur requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. His loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-start-up credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With the received credit Temur will purchase a car cheaply abroad and resell it then at a higher price. He plans to start this kind of business and hopes this will be a source of additional income for his family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a car to resell.

loans.name: Besik

texts.en:
Besik is 41 years old from a small village of Senaki district. He lives with his mother, who is provided with a retirement pension. Besik requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of his low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is from agricultural activities. In particular, they have a milking cow and two calves, whose milk is used in cheese production. Besides, they have a plot of agricultural land, where 1200 nut trees and maize are grown. 

Besik requested loan from Credo to start-up a family business. His loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-start-up credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With the received credit Besik will purchase piglets and build a shed for them. They will raise them and resell them at a higher price. This will increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and build a shed.

loans.name: Nino

texts.en:
Nino is 35 years old. She lives in a small village of Khashuri District with her husband, Mamuka, and three children (8, 11, and 14 years old). Nino requested a loan from local financial institutions several times, for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

Mamuka works as an artisan. He gets orders and makes wooden furniture.  Nino has a poultry business. She purchased chicks to raise, and she plans to sell them in about a month. Nino and Mamuka, together, earn hardly enough to provide food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Recently, Nino requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Her loan request was approved, in the frame of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The Start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and restart-up credits, with soft conditions, to rural poor people, who do not have access to other credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income.

With the received credit Nino will purchase additional chicks and feed for chicks. As she will buy another group of baby chicks, she will sell them after growing them for several months, and thus increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase chicks, raise them, and resell them for profit

loans.name: Lili

texts.en:
Lili is 45 years old. She lives in a small village of Telavi District, West Georgia with husband and son. Lili requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time, because of her low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is from agricultural activities. In particular, they have three pigs and a horse. Besides, they have a vineyard and sell grapes locally. It is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Lili requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-start-up credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With the received credit Lili will buy eight calves. After purchasing calves, she plans to raise them and when they are fattened properly she will resell them at a higher price. This will increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase 8 calves to raise and resell at a higher price.

loans.name: Elene

texts.en:
Elene is 26 years old. She lives in a small village in Tskaltubo District with her husband and two-year-old son. Their only source of income is from their farm. They have two milk cows that provide cheese to sell in the local markets. The money they make is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category.

Elene requested loans from local financial institutions several times to build a greenhouse, but without any success. Her loan applications were always rejected because of the family’s low income and poor living conditions, typical reasons for those regarded as high-risk borrowers.

Then Elene applied for a 2600 GEL start-up loan from Credo. It was approved within the framework of Credo and Kiva’s new joint initiative. This program provides both initial and successive business loans at more reasonable terms to country rural poor.

With her loan Elene and her husband will build their greenhouse. They will grow greens, cucumbers and tomatoes to sell and so increase their income. Credo’s new business initiative, financed through the assistance of Kiva lenders, will significantly improve the living conditions of Elene’s family.

loans.use: to build a greenhouse.

loans.name: Namie

texts.en:
Namie lives in Montserrado County the county of the capital city of Liberia, which is well known as the commercial city of Liberia. She is 32 years old, married, with two children aged 10 and 13 years old, who are in school and live at home. 

For the past ten years she has been selling dry fish in the community market. She started this business with the help of her husband and learned this way of selling from her mother. She spends eight hours a day in her business and she uses taxis most of the time to get her goods to her table. She said about herself 'I am business-minded and like my business because it gives me good profit'. 

She is requesting a loan to buy more dry fish to expand her sales. She wants to get more money to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more dry fish to expand her sales.

loans.name: Miatta

texts.en:
Miatta lives at Sinkor, which is a section of Monrovia, the capital city of Liberia, in Montserrado County. It is well-known as the commercial center of Liberia. Miatta is 25 years old, single, and has two children, aged 5 months and 7 years old.

For the past ten years she has been running a shop, where she sells grocery items like rice, soft drinks, pepper, and vita. She started this business with help from her father and learned this way of selling from him. She likes her business, because it gives her more profits and makes her popular. She spends nine hours on her business each day. She uses taxis to bring her stock to her shop. She will use her loan to buy more inventory items, like rice, soft drinks, pepper, vita, and others, for her business. She wants to get more money to build her house, since she has a piece of land.

loans.use: to buy more rice, soft drinks, pepper, vita, and other items to resell at her business

loans.name: Mriam Group

texts.en:
This group is called Mriam. It consists of three ladies and man who live in Aden, Yemen. Mriam is the leader of this group. She is 54 years old, married and has seven children who live in Sana`a, Yemen. She has been selling clothes for many years. She works hard to bring up her children and give them a good life. 

She said she has a small amount of money which she collected herself, but it is not enough to buy goods to expand her business. So she applied for a loan of 40,000 YER from AMB to buy clothes to use for her business.

loans.use: to buy clothes to use for her business.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe DANAYA sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans, et ont en moyenne  4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogamiques à  Médine, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur 14ème  prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme    FATOUMATA fait le commerce de pagnes et de tissus dans ce groupe de femmes. Elle se tient en deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt environ 20 pièces de pagnes qu’elle revend en détail sur place et au marché de Hamdallaye. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The four members of the group Danaya are married women who are on average 37 years old, and have on average 4 children. Most of them live in monogamous families in Médine, one of the popular neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali.

They are on their 14th loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso due to the concern of satisfying the needs of their clientele.

Madam Fatoumata sells pagnes [colorful African fabric] and fabric in this group of women. She is in the second position from left to right.

With her loan she plans to buy about 20 pieces of pagnes which she resells retail on the spot and at the market in Hamdallaye.

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA of which part is used to pay the loan and its interest and the other for her savings.

loans.use: to buy pagnes [colorful African fabric].

loans.name: Boldbaatar

texts.en:
Boldbaatar, 27 years old, lives with his wife and son in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia’s capital city. The family lives in their own house in a fenced yard.

Boldbaatar is a very hardworking individual who is striving for a better future. Since 2009 he has made and sold ore sample containers to mining enterprises. He also coordinates supplies of food and equipment for such businesses.

Over the years the house Boldbaatar and his family live in has deteriorated and needs some serious repairs. So he is applying for a 3,000,000 MNT loan from Credit Mongol to buy insulation and building materials such as fiberglass, foam, cotton, bricks, planks and cement to renovate and insulate his house. His family can then live in a warm and comfortable place.

A house renovated in this way can preserve heat, which will enable the family to burn less coal. This will contribute to Ulaanbaatar’s efforts to combat air pollution.

loans.use: to purchase insulation and building materials to repair his family's house.

loans.name: Watta K.

texts.en:
Watta lives in Montserrado County the county of the capital city of Liberia which is well known as the commercial city of Liberia. She is 42 years old, married, with three children between 14 and 22 years old; only one is in school and lives at home. 

Since 2007 she has been selling rubber dishes in the local market. She started this business with money from her husband and learned this way of selling from her mother. She spends eight hours a day in her business, and most of the time she uses the bus to get her goods to her shop.

She enjoys her business because of the profit she makes every day. She is requesting a loan to buy more rubber dishes (bowls, cups, plates, tubs etc) for her business. In the near future, she wants to build a house for her children.

loans.use: to buy more rubber dishes (bowls, cups, plates, tubs etc) for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fruits, vegetables, and groceries

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es: Gregoria invirtió su crédito en la compra de productos de aseo personal, como jabón, crema dental paños desechables, toallas, refrescos y cervezas. Su credikiva le fue de mucha ayuda porque pudo surtir su negocio, con productos que piden los visitantes y pacientes del hospital que tiene cerca. En la actualidad está aplicando aun nuevo credikiva con el cual comprará productos de aseo y refrescos, igualmente pondrá un techo en su apartamento y allí protegido ubicará su negocio actualmente ubicado en su interior. Su mensaje a los financiadores de Kiva es el siguiente: “Gracias, a esas personas que sin conocernos nos han ayudado, para que nuestros negocios progresen y salgamos adelante y que sigan apoyandononos.
texts.en:
Gregoria used her previous loan to buy personal hygiene products such as soaps, toothpaste, disposable diapers and sanitary napkins, as well as soft drinks and beer. Her Kiva loan was very helpful because she was able stock her store with products requested by visitors and patients of the nearby hospital. 

She is currently applying for a new Kiva loan, which she will use to purchase hygiene products and soft drinks as well as to install a new roof on her apartment. Then her business, which is currently located inside her home, will be protected. 

Her message to Kiva funders is this: "Thank you to those people who, without knowing us, have helped us so that our businesses move forward and improve. May you continue to support us."

loans.use: to purchase cleaning products and soft drinks as well as to install a new roof on her apartment

loans.name: Abla

texts.fr: Jeune dame de 33ans, madame Abla maman de 02 enfants dont 01  scolarisé a pour conjoint un revendeur. Elle est quant à elle revendeuse de yaourt depuis 2007. Son premier crédit effectué à WAGES lui servira d’acheter des sacs de lait, du sucre et des produits entrant dans la fabrication du yaourt. Elle espère réinvestir dans l’activité, en agrandissant la taille de son activité tout en assurant les moindres besoins de la famille.
texts.en: A young 33 year old woman, madam Abla is the mother of 2 children of whom 1 goes to school. Her spouse is a reseller. She is herself a reseller of yogurt and has been since 2007. Her first loan with WAGES will serve to buy bags of milk, sugar and products that go into the fabrication of yogurt. She hopes to reinvest in her business, growing the size of her business while ensuring the slightest needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy bags of milk, sugar and products that go into the fabrication of yogurt.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 35 year old and married with six children between the ages of four and nineteen. She lives in Sinkor, a neighborhood within Monrovia, the capital city of Liberia.

For the past three years Rebecca has been selling fish from a table in the market. She started this business with the help of her father and learned how to sell from him. She enjoys selling for the profits it brings and because it makes her popular and well-known.

Rebecca is requesting a 35,000 LRD loan from BRAC Liberia to buy more fish for her business. With her anticipated profits she wants to build her family a house.

loans.use: to buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce lives in Sinkor, one of the areas where the living condition is almost like that of the people who live in the center of Monrovia. She is 38 years old, married, with three children between the ages of 12 to 20. Two are in school and only one lives at home. 

For 16 years, Joyce has been involved in the sales of foodstuff, like rice and pepper. Sometimes, her customers buy on credit and don’t pay on time. She learned this way of selling from her friends and she likes her business because it gives her money. 

Joyce is requesting a loan to purchase rice, pepper, oil, coal, etc. for her business. Her plan is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase rice, pepper, oil, coal, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca lives in Montserrado County the county of the capital city of Liberia, which is well known as the commercial city of Liberia. She is 24 years old, single with a four-year-old child who is in school and lives at home.

For the past two years she has been selling used clothes in the local market. She started this business with money from her husband and learned this way of selling from her mother. She enjoys her business because of the profit she makes every day. 

She is requesting a loan to buy more used clothes for her business. In the near future, she wants to build a house for her child.

loans.use: to buy more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Gormah

texts.en:
Gormah is running a shop in Gbarnga, the Capital City of Bong County where she has lots of materials for sale. She started this business with help from her father, and learned this style of selling from her father.

Presently the problem she faces is she doesn't have enough capital to expand her business. She is requesting a loan to buy more used clothes for her business. She spends nine hours a day in her business. She enjoys this business because its keep her busy. She is a 6th grade student; she is 48 years old, married with eight children whose ages are between 14 and 34. Only one is in school and lives at home. 

Her dream is to expand her business even more and build a house.

loans.use: to buy more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife is 40 years old, married, with two children. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. To earn a living, she owns and operates a retail business in the local community. She has been in her business for over seven years and earns PHP 10,000 every month. 

Marife joined Gata Daku Multi-Purpose Cooperative (GDMPC) in 2010 and now she has requested a loan of PHP 12,000 to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods, sugar, coffee, shampoo, and noodles. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods, sugar, coffee, shampoo, and noodles.

loans.name: Ojar

texts.ru:
Ожар жительница района Джиликул. Ей 50 лет. Она замужем. У нее трое детей. Муж Ожар находится на заработках в России. Ожар имеет среднее образование. Она на протяжении восьми лет занимается растениеводством. В этой области у нее имеется богатый опыт. У Ожар при доме имеется участок земли, где она выращивает сельскохозяйственные культуры для продажи. 
Ожар берет кредит для закупа минеральных удобрений для урожая пшеницы и лука.
texts.en: Ojar is a resident of the Jilikul region of Tajikistan.  She is 50 years old, married, and has 3 children.  Ojar's husband is a migrant worker in Russia.  She has a higher education and has worked in agriculture for the last 8 years.  She has much experience in this area.  Ojar has a plot of land near her home where she grows crops to sale.  She is taking out a loan for mineral fertilizers for her wheat and onion crops.

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizers for wheat and onion crops

loans.name: Lala

texts.en:
Lala is 18 years old. She lives in Akhalkalaki District with her brother, sister and mother. Lala requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

Lala works at a local hotel as an administrator, and her mother works as a housekeeper. They both get a small monthly income. It is hardly enough to provide food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Recently, Lala requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Her loan request was approved, in the frame of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The Start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and restart-up credit, with soft conditions, to rural poor people, who do not have access to other credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income.

With the received credit Lala will trade in clothing. She plans to purchase clothing from the wholesalers and then resell at higher prices among the neighbors. This will increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to begin a new business, selling clothing

loans.name: Garmai

texts.en:
Garmai lives in Sinkor. This is an area where the living conditions are almost the same as those of the people who live in the center of Monrovia. She is 39 years old, unmarried with six children aged between four and 20. 

For the past 16 years now she has been selling fish on a table in the local market. She  started this business by selling with money given to her by her fiancee and learned this way of selling from her mother. She likes her business because it gives her good profits and makes her popular.

She is requesting a loan to buy more fish for her business. She wants to get more money to build her house and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Percilia

texts.en:
Percelia lives in Montserrado county, Sinkor. This is an area that is almost like the center of Monrovia. She is 28 years old, and lives together with her boyfriend and two children aged 8 and 12. Her children are attending school.

She has been running a table in the local market for the past eight years where she sells pepper, rice, palm oil, vita, onion, okra, etc. She uses the profits from her business for food and the rent for her house. She started this business with money from her boyfriend. She spends eight hours a day in her business, and enjoys the response she gets from her customers. She uses a taxi to get her goods to her table from the wholesale store.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more pepper, rice, palm oil, vita, onion, okra, etc for her business. Her plan is to own a car to use in her business.

loans.use: to purchase more pepper, rice, palm oil, vita, onion and okra for her business.

loans.name: Rena F.

texts.en:
Rena F. lives in Sinkor, an area where the living conditions are almost like those of the people who live in the center of Monrovia. She is 24 years old, single and has six-year-old child who attends school and lives at home. She is a university student. 

For seven years now she has been involved in the sale of soap, candles, biscuits, sugar etc. Sometimes her customers take goods on credit and don’t pay on time. She learned this way of selling from her mother, and she likes her business because it makes her self-sufficient. She is requesting a loan to purchase soap, candles, biscuits, sugar etc for her business. Her plan is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase soap, candles, biscuits and sugar for her business.

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy is 34 years old and married with two children. She lives in Clarin in Misamis Occidental district. She grows bananas to earn a living. She has done so for over five years and earns 9,000 PHP a month.

In 2011 Juvy joined GDMPC. She is applying for a 11,500 PHP loan to buy pesticides for her banana trees. She plans to use any additional profits to improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to buy pesticides for her banana trees.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy 200 bras

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.ru: Дилором вдова с четырьмя детьми. Ей 35 лет. Она со своими детьми живет у матери в Яванском районе. Ее отец в настоящее время выехал на заработки в заграницу. Сама Дилором уже 12 лет как работает в сфере торговли. У нее имеется магазин, где она занимается продажей одежды и обуви. С целью увеличения товарообоорта Дилором обратилась за кредитом. Она просит кредит для приобретения сезонной одежды. За счет прибыли в дальнейшем Дилором планирует приобрести землю и построить свой дом.
texts.en: Dilorom is a widow and the mother of four children.  She's 35 years old and lives with children and mother in the Yavan region of Tajikistan.  Her father is a migrant worker in another country.  Dilorom has worked in trade for more than 12 years.  She has a store where she sells clothing and footwear.  With the goal of increasing turnover, Dilorom has decided to take out a loan to buy seasonal clothing.  She plans to buy land and build her own home with the profits.

loans.use: To buy seasonal clothing

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is 43 years old, married, with three children. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. To earn a living, she owns and operates a motorcycle transport service in the local community. She has been in her business for over five years and earns PHP 10,000 every month. 

She joined Gata Daku Multi-Purpose Cooperative (GDMPC) in 2011 and now she has requested a loan of PHP 12,000 to purchase spare parts and tires. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and tires for her motorcycle.

loans.name: Shiela

texts.en:
Shiela is 31 years old, married, with two children. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. To earn a living, she owns and operates farmland, planting and harvesting bananas. She has been in her business for over five years and earns PHP 5,000 every month. 

Shiela joined Gata Daku Multi-Purpose Cooperative (GDMPC) and requested a loan of PHP 6,000 to purchase chemicals for banana production. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase chemicals for banana production.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn is 41 years old and married with five children. She lives in Clarin in Misamis Occidental district. For the past six years she has grown and sold coconuts to earn a living. She makes approximately 5,000 a month.

Merlyn joined GDMPC in 2010. She is applying for a 6,500 PHP loan to buy pesticides for her coconut trees. She plans to use all new profits to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy pesticides for her coconut trees.

loans.name: Cindy

texts.en:
Cindy, 53 years old, is married and has three children. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She owns and operates a retail business in the local community to earn a living. She has been in her business for over eight years and earns PHP 3,000 every month.

She has been a member of GDMPC since the year 2011, and now she has requested a loan of PHP 4,500. She will use it to purchase additional products to sell in her store, like canned goods, sugar, coffee and noodles. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods, sugar, coffee and noodles

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 30 years old and married, with 4 children. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. 

Josephine owns and operates a retail business in the local community to earn a living; she has been in business for more than four years, and earns PHP 5,000 monthly. 

She joined GDMPC in 2010, and now she has requested a loan of PHP 6,500 to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods, noodles, sugar, and coffee. 

She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods, noodles, sugar, and coffee.

loans.name: Santas

texts.en:
Santas is married, and works hard to support her family.

She has an upholstery business in the Philippines, and makes additional income from furniture making.  Santas would like to borrow 495,000 Philippines Pesos through NWTF to buy tools and equipment for her upholstery business.

Santas has been sustaining her business activities through 16 previous loans from NWTF, most recently in partnership with Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her to achieve her dream of saving some money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy tools and equipment for her upholstery business.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is 50 years old, married, and has six children. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She owns and operates a copra production business, to earn a living. She has been in her business for over six years and earns PHP 5,000 every month.

She has been a member of GDMPC since the year 2010, and now she has requested a loan of PHP 7,000. She will use it to purchase additional coconuts, from which to make copra. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business, to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional coconuts from which to make copra

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a 54-year-old married woman who has been blessed with nine children. She has managed a pig raising business for almost 10 years. She earns a net income of 3,500 Philippines Pesos (PHP) for every pig she sells. 

Maria would like to take a loan of 15,000 PHP to buy more pigs to raise, and to buy pig food. She hopes that her loan will be granted so that she can improve her livestock business.

loans.use: To purchase pigs to raise, and to buy pig food.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 38 years old, and married with three children. Nancy works very hard to provide for her children, one of whom is still in school.

She runs a general store in the Philippines, and has asked for a loan of 13,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her store.

Nancy has been in this business for 3 years, and sells a variety of things such as canned goods, bread, soft-drinks and seasonings. 

In the future Nancy would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her store.

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
La señora Maria de estado civil unida de hecho, tiene 29 años de edad, tiene 2 hijos que no estudian, ella se dedica a la artesanía, especificamente al bordado de guipiles para damas, inició este negocio cuando su suegra le enseño este arte y hasta la presente fecha lleva ya 10 años de dichosa experiencia. Ella cuanta con el apoyo de su esposo quien es comerciante.

Organiza un grupo para poder solicitar un préstamo que lo utilizara para la compra de telas e hilos para poder realizar sus bordados, en el futuro quiere tener una tienda para vender los guipiles que borda; las demás integrantes del grupo se dedican a la artesania y actividades pecuarias.

Una de las integrantes del grupo no figura en la foto puesto que cuando se tomaron la misma ella no pudo asistir.
texts.en:
Señora Maria is in a domestic partnership, is 29 years old and has 2 children who do not attend school. She works as an artisan, more specifically embroidering guipiles [Guatemalan tunics] for women. She started this business when her mother-in-law taught her this art form. She now has 10 years of experience working in this field. She has the support of her spouse, who is a merchant.

She is organizing a group in order to apply for a loan, which she will use to purchase fabric and thread to carry out her embroidering.
